item.title: Assignment 2
item.description: For this writing assignment, you will think about what you mean by the meaning of life. You’ll discuss that in a structured way. Upload your paper through Blackboard upload, under the Assignments button, any day or time before the end of Monday, December 7. Please don’t write your name at the top, so I can provide some anonymous feedback. After a brief, introductory, summarizing paragraph which you should write last, after you’ve written all the rest, but place first, construct the following paragraphs.

item.title: Test 2 Questions
item.description: Instructions To take this test, you do not need to log in to Zoom. All the instructions appear below. However, there will be a Zoom session open during our assigned exam time (10:30–12:30), where you can find me on chat. After that, please contact me through email with any questions. The following questions are designed to take you not more than 90 minutes. This is a final assessment, not a big project.

item.title: Test 1 Questions
item.description: Here are the questions for the first test. The test will be from a subset of these questions. For each question, write at least five sentences (minimum) and perhaps a bit more than five. Write concisely and informatively. If there is more than one part to the question, make sure to answer all the parts. What is Blackburn’s “middle-ground” defense of philosophy. What is Blackburn’s “low-ground” defense of philosophy. In Apology, what does Socrates say is the greatest good for a human being (“a man”), and what does he say that supports that?

item.title: Assignment 1
item.description: Your main task is to identify and reconstruct an argument about the meaning of life and then critically evaluate it. Based on how well you think it works for this task, choose one of the following: (1) the Steve Jobs speech, or (2) a different speech or text you’ve found and cleared with me in advance. That will be your “source text.” From your source text, reconstruct a statement of the form “The meaning of life is …” or “The way to live is ….

item.title: Participation Rubric
item.description: This is the participation rubric to be used for grading participation in this course. Read it as saying “A student who demonstrates … earns a grade of X,” where X is the letter grade at the top of the column.1 A B C D F Active role in discussions, drawing on texts Regular, constructive participation drawing on texts Inconsistent constructive participation based on texts Vague comments reflecting limited engagement with texts Persistent lack of engagement with texts Full preparation for approximately every class Substantial preparation, normally Inconsistent evidence of preparation Rare evidence of participation No positive evidence of participation Success at advancing level and depth of discussion, persistently Regular contributions based on assigned material, which sometimes improve discussion and never diminish it Rare or no significant contribution to the level of discussion while not reducing it Activity sometimes diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Activity regularly diminishing the discussion and the classroom environment Active engagement with and listening to peers, persistently Sincere efforts to interact with peers, normally Limited engagement with peers Rare interaction with peers No interaction with peers This rubric is significantly based on, and lightly adapted from, one written by another philosophy professor, Jay Odenbaugh.
